message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers indicate primary biliary cholangitis. The most likely finding on liver biopsy is lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas. Option A describes findings in primary sclerosing cholangitis, while option B describes alcoholic liver disease and option C describes nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers suggest primary biliary cholangitis, which is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas. Fibrous, concentric obliteration of small and large bile ducts is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis, macrovesicular fatty infiltration and necrosis of hepatocytes is seen in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and ballooning degeneration and apoptosis of hepatocytes are seen in alcoholic hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which is characterized by elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers and may lead to liver cirrhosis. Biopsy findings of PBC include lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas. Option A describes primary sclerosing cholangitis, option B describes nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and option C describes ballooning degeneration in patients with hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers suggest the patient may have primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which is commonly associated with lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas. Fibrous, concentric obliteration of small and large bile ducts is characteristic of primary sclerosing cholangitis, which is not associated with elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers. Macrovesicular fatty infiltration and necrosis of hepatocytes and ballooning degeneration and apoptosis of hepatocytes are characteristic of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and viral hepatitis infections, respectively, and do not typically present with pruritus or elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and serum studies suggest primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). Elevated serum antimitochondrial antibody titers indicate autoimmune involvement of the liver. The characteristic histologic finding of PBC is lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers suggest primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas. Fibrous, concentric obliteration of small and large bile ducts is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. Macrovesicular fatty infiltration and necrosis of hepatocytes are seen in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Ballooning degeneration and apoptosis of hepatocytes are seen in alcoholic liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and serum studies suggest primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), and the elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers support this diagnosis. The biopsy of PBC typically shows lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas. Options A, B, and C are not consistent with the diagnosis of PBC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and elevated antimitochondrial antibody titers suggest primary biliary cholangitis. The liver biopsy is most likely to show lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas, which are characteristic features of the disease. Option A is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis, option B is seen in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and option C is seen in alcoholic liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and laboratory findings suggest primary biliary cholangitis, which is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas, and fibrous obliteration of small and large bile ducts. The correct answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and elevated antimitochondrial antibody suggest primary biliary cholangitis. The most likely biopsy finding is lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas, which are hallmarks of the disease. The other options are characteristics of other liver diseases such as nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, alcoholic hepatitis, and primary sclerosing cholangitis.
